Notes: Sequel to All In: Comedy About Love which recouped its $4.8M in just 10 weeks. Same format: rotating celebrity comedians with live band. Hit $2M+ weekly gross (record for a play). Very lean $200-300K weekly costs with 4-performer format. LIMITED RUN through March 8, 2026 - did NOT receive NY tax credit (missed application deadline by 2 months). Stars include Sarah Silverman, Ray Romano, Jason Mantzoukas.
Broadway premiere at MTC's Samuel J. Friedman Theatre. Tracy Letts play directed by David Cromer. Transferred from Steppenwolf. Carrie Coon stars. Critics' Pick.

Revival with Lea Michele and Aaron Tveit. Selling out regularly at ~$1.3-1.8M/week gross. Break-even ~$1.1M. Qualified for $3M NY theater tax credit (first preview Oct 15, 2025, just before Oct 20 deadline). At ~$500K weekly profit, could recoup by closing (June 14, 2026). Original 1988 production was $6M.

Closed Feb 1, 2026 without recouping after ~3 month run. Strong reviews but struggled at box office (~$0.5-0.6M weekly). Transferred from Off-Broadway at Roundabout. Eligible for NY State 25% theater tax credit (up to $3M) which will soften investor losses. Critics' Pick.
25th Anniversary Tour Broadway engagement (Aug 2025 - Feb 2026). See mamma-mia-2001 for original production.
Second Stage Theater production at Helen Hayes Theatre. Jordan Harrison play. Star cast: June Squibb, Cynthia Nixon, Danny Burstein. Critics' Pick.
Mark Strong + Lesley Manville. West End production recouped separately. Broadway limited engagement sold out every performance. Critics' Pick. Likely to recoup given strong sales.
Lincoln Center Theater revival. LCT operates on subscriber/nonprofit model - doesn't seek traditional recoupment. 32-member cast, 28-piece orchestra. Extended through June 2026. 100% capacity.
Closed early Dec 2025 after weak ticket sales. Stephen Schwartz score. Kristin Chenoweth star vehicle couldn't save production.

Show: Two Strangers (Carry a Cake Across New York)
Notes: Forbes: 'most investor friendly new musical since the pandemic' - $8M cap with $480K weekly nut (two-hander with minimal production). Break-even ~$550K. Typical gross $0.65-0.75M at 80-95% capacity. MISSED NY tax credit deadline (first paid performance Nov 1, 2025 was after Oct 20 cutoff). Despite modest grosses, low overhead means it's hovering near break-even.
Big-budget extravaganza capitalized at $26M. Closed July 2025 after missing Tony momentum. Fixed weekly expenses of $817K. Jasmine Amy Rogers praised but couldn't save production.

Producer Orin Wolf noted it 'only cost $17 million' - modest for 2025 musical. Won 5 Tony Awards. Typical weekly gross $0.9-1.0M at 90-95% capacity. Break-even ~$0.85M. Broadway Journal: 'if they can weather the next year... may recoup in 12-18 months.' Eligible for $3M NY tax credit.

Most expensive show of 2024-2025 season. Grossed $63M+ in 46 weeks with $1.0-1.1M weekly costs. On track to recoup Spring 2026. Eligible for $3M NY tax credit (25% of costs up to $12M). Break-even ~$1.2M weekly.

Jonathan Groff star vehicle. Bobby Darin jukebox musical with $9.4M cap and $600K weekly costs. Averaging $1.2M+ weekly gross - recoupment imminent (likely Feb 2026). Strong reviews and Groff's star power driving consistent sales.
Critics' Pick. Darren Criss + Helen J Shen. Small cast reduces running costs. Struggled financially early but has been selling out consistently.
First show of 2024-2025 season to recoup. Transferred from sold-out Off-Broadway run. Set Lyceum box office records.

West End hit transferred to Broadway. Weekly costs $500K vs London's Â£100K. Break-even ~$600K weekly but averaging $580K - running below break-even. Extended through Feb 2026 on strong word-of-mouth despite soft grosses.
Limited run with Jim Parsons. First Thornton Wilder play to gross $1M+ in a week. Strong final weeks. Capitalized at $20M. Closed Jan 2025.

Netflix/Sonia Friedman production. Won 4 Tony Awards 2025. RECOUPED December 2025 - grossed $57M+ in 40 weeks with $1M/week costs = $17M+ profit toward $20M cap. Set Marquis Theatre record of $2.51M during Christmas week 2025. Season 5 finale boosted ticket sales significantly.
Star vehicle for Patti LuPone and Mia Farrow. Limited run closed as scheduled Jan 2025. Low capitalization compared to other Broadway shows.

Show: Back to the Future: The Musical
Notes: Closed Jan 2025 after struggling to find audience. West End production more successful. High-tech production couldn't compensate for middling reviews.

Show: Cabaret at the Kit Kat Club
Notes: Closed Oct 2025 without recouping. Theatre conversion cost ~$8M. Investor lawsuit filed alleging financial mismanagement. High weekly nut of $1.5M proved unsustainable.
Closing Feb 2026 without recouping. Won 2 Tonys + Grammy. Grossed $100M+ but high running costs prevented recoupment. International productions planned.
Record 13 Tony nominations for a play. Recouped just before closing Jan 2025. National tour and West End transfer announced.
Won Tony for Best Original Score but closed Jan 2025 without recouping. Shaina Taub won two Tonys.

First Broadway musical led by Korean producer (OD Company). BroadwayWorld: 'now appears unlikely' to recoup - grosses declined ~$250K/week in 2025 vs 2024. Break-even ~$1.0M but recent weeks at $0.9M (82% capacity). Eligible for $3M NY tax credit. Lavish Jazz Age production with 22-person cast, Tony-winning costumes.
Among the more modestly budgeted musicals of 2023-24 season. Ingrid Michaelson score. Three-actor casting concept for one character was innovative but didn't drive sustained sales. Closed Dec 2024.

Won Best Musical Tony 2024. Recouped $22M investment week ending December 28, 2025 after 744 performances (~89 weeks) and $121M total grosses. First new musical to recoup since 2022. Post-Tony grosses hit $1.4M/week record at Bernard B. Jacobs Theatre.
Closed without recouping despite 7 Tony nominations. Spending not apparent in modest sets. Strong reviews couldn't overcome weak ticket sales.
Fourth new musical to recoup post-pandemic. Max Martin jukebox catalogue drives consistent grosses.
Recouped in ~16 months. Received $10M SVOG grant. Has grossed over $200M. National tour also profitable.
Low capitalization + strong grosses = quick recoupment. Received $10M SVOG grant. Multiple touring productions.
Recouped ~3 years after opening. Lavish production design. Has grossed $194M+ on Broadway.
First musical of 2018-2019 season to recoup. Won 8 Tony Awards including Best Musical. Grosses have softened recently but remains profitable.

Show: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child
Notes: Most expensive play ever to recoup. Condensed from two-part to single show post-pandemic. 5+ years profitable, grossing $2.1M/wk at 96% capacity.

Recouped Broadway investment in ~10 weeks (often reported as '6 months' including Off-Broadway run at Public Theater). Currently grossing $600k+ weekly in profit. Multiple productions worldwide. Estimated total profit exceeds $1B.

Recouped within ~9 months (by mid-December 2014). Disney never announces recoupments -- per insider: 'recoupment is not a concept that makes sense in the Disney model' since they handle many services in-house. By May 2023: $561M+ grossed, 3,100+ performances. Received $3M NY theater tax credit. Disney's unique New Amsterdam lease pays 2% of gross as rent (vs standard fixed rent), affecting cost calculations.
Recouped in ~9 months. Multiple touring and international productions. Investors received multiple returns.
Recouped in ~26 months (just over 2 years). Has grossed over $1.4B on Broadway alone. Film adaptation boosted 2024-2025 grosses significantly.
Broadway's highest-grossing show of all time at $2B+. First show to hit $1B milestone (2013). Still running after 27+ years.
Longest-running American musical in Broadway history. $700M+ Broadway gross. Low-cost concert staging was revolutionary.
